answers.author: Robert Woods
answers.text:
You should question if you need this software at all. If you have EXCEL you have the esy ability to store information and generate chargs and graphs, and do trend analysis.
We use SQL Server to store data in a database, or to query our other systems such as our accounting systems. You can do a lot using Reporting Services which comes with SQL Server, or by downloading the information into EXCEL if you want. That saves a lot of money.
Having a piece of software is not the most critical thing. The real problem is making sure you collect the right metrics, do so regularly, and keep on top of them. 
Most importantly, you need to develop the internal human capital to use the information you generate, and to be able to perform the assessment of what it means. It's not how cool the graphs look, or the meters that appear on the screen, it's being able to  understand why things are happening and how you can improve your management to get the results you want.

answers.author: Thomas Quist
answers.text:
Hi Sarah,
This is a good question.  I have done a little research into PM software, and have yet to find anything truly inspiring.  I do agree with Robert that Excel is probably a great solution.  Someone recently reminded me of the saying that we only use about 5% of our brain - an apt metaphor for Excel.  Excel is quite capable, and everyone already has it.  I suggest, if you have the time, spend some time learning some of the more advanced functions of Excel such as defined names and "dynamic charts."  These two features alone are quite powerful and would allow you to generate charts that automatically update when you enter new data, allowing you to spend more time analyzing the data rather than creating charts.  You can do some pretty amazing things, though it does take time to develop the expertise required to really make Excel perform at a high level.
I am attaching an "Excel Spreadsheet" I developed in house for the City of Cartersville.  I have tried to incorporate several of the best practices of data visualization (avoiding eye candy, distractions, and "bad" charts such as pie charts, 3D charts, and speedometer charts).  You will find two charts types called "sparklines" and "bullet charts" which are used throughout the dashboard.  There is a built in tutorial which will tell you how to interpret them, along with describing other features of the dashboard such as interactivity.  You will need to enable macros for the dashboard to function properly.
While at this time this model is not generic enough to be easily transferable to other organizations, I have been working on my own time to develop something which could be shared more easily.  I just wanted to share to show you what Excel is capable of.
Sincerely,
Tom

answers.author: Randy Webster
answers.text:
I endorse the opinions of Bob and Thomas. Over 20 years of working with performance measures I have found that the hard work is not the software. The hard work is in clarifying strategy, goals, and outcomes and then establishing metrics that inform progress towards goals and outcomes. Harder still is the continual effort to link metrics to decision-making. Standard data management and analysis tools like MS Access, SQL, and Excel are more than adequate.  We are now looking to posting performance results on a website for easy user access, but content will still be generated in Excel. Furthermore, questions asked of the data evolve. Stable time-series measures are valuable, but it's also great to be able to analyze the data set to address new questions. Having the data in your own tools like Access & Excel maximize this flexibility. Good luck.

answers.author: Thomas Quist
answers.text:
Randy, you make some great points.  I think you have identified some of the key components to a successful performance management program - and you are right in that there needs to be a strong foundation including a strategic plan and goals to give the program direction.  
It is important, however, to make good use of your data once you have it.  Do your tools allow you to interact with the data?  Do they allow you to experiment with different views and comparisons?  Do you spend more time creating reports than studying them?  I think there is room for some enhancements beyond simple time series bar or line charts.  This is where a potential opportunity to implement dedicated software/programming comes in.
I thoroughly agree that the flexibility offered by Excel is one of its main strengths.  In addition, the familiarity of the environment to almost all office employees is another huge bonus. 
Tom

answers.author: Thomas Quist
answers.text:
Sarah,
A couple more points - sorry for going on and on, but I really enjoy discussing this stuff!
First - a question for you.  Who do you envision using this software?  Is it intended to generate reports for the public?  Is it geared towards staff (analysts, managers)?  Depending on the answer to that question, you will have different needs.  
Public reports are generally going to have to be simpler, using familiar charts (bar, line, pie, etc).  Many jurisdictions have made use of various software packages that can take data (usually from Excel) and create flash based charts that can be hosted on a website.  There is often some interactivity (selecting different measures, mostly).  I would submit that these programs aren't very well suited for an analyst.  While Excel is great for storing data in this case, Excel does not play all that nice with the web, unless you are generating a "static" report that can be printed to pdf and uploaded to your website (that's what we currently do).
On the other hand, internal reports, which staff can be trained to use/interpret, can be much more complex.  This is where Excel is much more capable and flexible (see my previous comments and the City of Cartersville's example dashboard for further clarification).
In the end, the biggest problem I have with Excel is it's inability to work well with the web.  However, to me, the pros outweigh the cons by a long shot.
As I mentioned above, I do recommend familiarizing yourself with some of the more advanced functions of Excel.  If you have some time (about an hour, I believe), you can check out this recording of a Webinar I did with the ICMA Center for Performance Measurement where I explained some of the essential techniques for building your own dashboard:
http://icma.org/Documents/Document/Document/303256
Unfortunately, the video quality isn't great, and the sound is worse!  Perhaps it will help.
Other resources I recommend include:
excelhero.com
chandoo.org
mrexcel.com/forum (you can ask questions here when you run into a problem, and various Excel loving geeks will gladly help you, surprisingly quickly).
Also, if you'd like to chat on the phone, I'm always happy to do so.  I can be reached at (770)607-2111.  My email is tquist@cityofcartersville.org
Tom

answers.author: Randy Webster
answers.text:
Tom,
We (the analytical types) interact with the data a lot. We use Excel for smaller data sets, Access + Excel for large data sets via ODBC queries into Excel pivot tables for analysis, and SPSS for statistical work, especially customer and citizen surveys, and of course GIS for the spatial analysis. We do spend more time exploring and analyzing data than writing reports. 
That said, we have not yet taken the step of providing interactive performance data for our managers and citizens. It would great, but requires another level of data management and IT support that we don't have now. 
I agree with you assessment of Excel and its limitations for web interaction. Some other solution would be necessary to make interactive data on the web sing. My largest frustration with Excel are the limitations in graphical presentation and native graph types.
My initial comments were meant to encourage focus on the purpose of performance metrics, a solid foundation, and high quality analysis without becoming distracted by the platform or chartjunk.
Cheers

In a past professional life, I used Access to do a lot of work with data collection. You can easily create overlays to help reduce errors in data entry and export your data to other programs for charting/graphing. 
Newer versions of Excel have better graphics features, but my wife has used Google motion charts with relative ease for showing data:
http://code.google.com/apis/chart/interactive/docs/index.html
Hans Rosling really made this method of presenting data famous at a TED talk: http://bit.ly/GDz8J8

author: Sarah Saunders
text:
The City of Tamarac is exploring the possibility of purchasing a performance management software that we can use to track our performance measures, create trend analyses, generate reports, etc. Does your organization currently use such a software? If so, we are interested in learning more about it. Some of our questions are as follows:

What is the name of the company?
What is the cost of the software? Do you lease or own?
Can you tell me a little about the start-up process? Was it an easy transition?
What do you currently use the software for? Where did you previously collect this information?
What are the pros/cons about the software your organization is using?

Any suggestions, feedback, or reviews of performance management software will be greatly appreciated!
title: Does your organization use a Performance Management Software?
